text: We are under attack by #COVID19. Trump's nomination decision again shows he will put protecting himself ahead of protecting taxpayers ‚Äî weakening the integrity of a bipartisan program to help American families, workers, and small businesses during this national emergency.

The job requires a background independent from politics, free from special interests. It‚Äôs impossible to imagine that someone currently serving the White House and who was involved in the president‚Äôs defense during his impeachment trial meets these criteria.

The person in this role must provide robust apolitical oversight to ensure $2T of taxpayer dollars gets to those who need it most during this crisis, not wasted on CEO bonuses, stock buybacks or dividends, or payments to those who don‚Äôt need it.

STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS ‚ñ∂Ô∏è a total of $150 billion placed in a new Coronavirus Relief Fund, which state, tribal and local governments can use to meet costs connected to the virus. California will receive $15.3 billion, more than any other state.

FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS ‚ñ∂Ô∏è $100 billion for hospitals and health care providers on the front lines, $1.32 billion for community health centers, and $4.3 billion for local and state public health agencies to purchase crucial #PPE, lab testing, and other preparedness activities.

FOR STUDENTS ‚ñ∂Ô∏è $30 billion to schools in emergency funding, paused payments for federal student loan borrowers and makes employer-provided student loan assistance tax free (thanks to my bill, the Employer Participation in Repayment Act!).

FOR SMALL BUSINESSES ‚ñ∂Ô∏è $377 billion infusion with @SBAgov emergency grants of up to $10,000 and eligibility for SBA loan forgiveness for payroll, mortgage interest, rent and utility costs. 

Read the Small Business Owner‚Äôs Guide to the CARES Act: https://t.co/nHeDMJFgCD

FOR WORKERS ‚ñ∂Ô∏è $260 billion invested in Unemployment Insurance, and an additional 13 weeks of federally-funded benefits.

Visit our worker support page for more information: 
https://t.co/gvj2Nnf3Ac

FOR AMERICANS ‚ñ∂Ô∏è $1,200 of immediate assistance per individual and up to $3,400 for a family of four, prohibits foreclosures on all federally-backed mortgages for 60 days and prohibits eviction filings for 120 days.

Individual taxpayers who need additional time to file beyond the July 15 deadline can request a filing extension by filing Form 4868 through their tax professional, tax software or using the Free File link on https://t.co/TGSsNgzJeB

This deferment applies to all individuals, trusts and estates, corporations and other non-corporate tax filers as well as those who pay self-employment tax. Taxpayers don't need to file any additional forms or call the IRS to qualify for this automatic filing and payment relief.

#ICYMI, #TaxDay has been moved: the due date for 2019 federal income tax returns has been extended from April 15, 2020, to July 15, 2020, which means taxpayers can defer tax payments until July 15 without penalties and interest, regardless of the amount owed.

‚òëÔ∏è The Protecting Business Opportunities for Veterans Act would protect veteran-owned small businesses by directing the VA to work with the VA OIG to identify and penalize small businesses who take advantage of the Vets First Program, reducing the fraud and abuse in contracting.

‚òëÔ∏è The VA Reporting Transparency Act would require the VA to launch and maintain a website that includes all public reports to Congress, increasing transparency and accessibility to better serve the veteran community.

‚òëÔ∏è The Legal Services for Homeless Veterans Act would strengthen the help available to veterans facing certain legal issues that could lead them on a path to homelessness by establishing VA grants for organizations that provide legal services to homeless or at-risk vets.
‚òëÔ∏è The GIVE Act would require the VA to provide additional information for the GI Bill Comparison Tool, important to veterans trying to decide which college to attend.

‚òëÔ∏è The Gold Star Spouses and Spouses of Injured Servicemembers Leasing Relief Expansion Act would allow spouses of critically injured service members to terminate property and automobile leases, and surviving spouses to terminate automobile leases.

This week, the House passed five bipartisan bills to help veterans, their families, and surviving spouses. Each would ensure greater support for American vets and service members who are transitioning to civilian life. https://t.co/sp8Y1FSANO

Our job is to serve the American public, not big corporations that dump unlimited amounts of money into politics. HR1 keeps special interests in check and bolsters the interests of the American people. The House has done our part. It's time for the Senate to vote on this bill.

HR1, the #ForThePeople Act, fights back against dark money:
‚òëÔ∏èTightening rules on super PACs.
‚òëÔ∏èStrengthening standards for political advertising.
‚òëÔ∏èBanning campaign contributions from foreign nationals.
‚òëÔ∏èDemanding transparency through disclosure of dark money donations.

10 years ago, the SCOTUS‚Äôs ruling on Citizens United opened the floodgates to dark money in politics. Americans know we need greater transparency into campaign finance, which is why the House passed #HR1 within the first 100 days of the new Congress last year.
